species_data.label: Southern Bell Frog
species_data.searchText: Southern Bell Frog Growling Grass Warty Bell Litoria raniformis
species_data.description: Body bright green with golden coloured patches on the back, and a pale stripe along the middle of the back. Back covered in wart lumps. Groin and legs with purple-pink patches. Up to 11 cm long.
species_data.biology: Southern Bell Frogs produce a secretion through glands in the skin which can have a toxic effect on other animals, and can cause skin irritation in humans. Females can be 4 cm larger than the males.
species_data.habitat: Near water in woodland and shrubland areas.
species_data.otherNames: Growling Grass Frog, Warty Bell Frog

images.credit: Simon Sherrin slash me / Museum Victoria

species_data.searchText: Southern Bell Frog Growling Grass Warty Bell Litoria raniformis

species_data.label: Wandering Albatross
species_data.searchText: birds albatrosses wandering albatross diomedea exulans
species_data.description: Body mainly white. Wings white on leading edge and centre, tips and trailing edge black. Underwing mainly white, tips and trailing edge black. Bill pink. Young birds: body and upperwing uniform brown, face white. Body up to 1.4 m long, wing span to 3.5 m.
species_data.biology: The wingspan of these albatrosses is the widest of all ocean birds. Individuals breed on sub-Antarctic islands, mainly in the Indian Ocean and New Zealand waters.
species_data.habitat: Coastlines, large bays and open seas.
species_data.distinctive: Wide wingspan, white body, pink bill, white underwing with black tips and trailing edge.
species_data.distribution: Southern continents. Southern Australia, including across Victoria.

species_data.label: Thermocolour grasshopper
species_data.description: Males: turquoise when warm, black when cold. Females: three colour morphs - all brown, dark green/brown or brown with pink head. Both sexes have orange-yellow legs and very small wings. Sexes can be distinguished by size.
species_data.biology: Adults die in late Autumn after laying eggs in the soil; eggs overwinter under the snow and hatch in late spring; nymphs (approximately 5mm long) can be seen from early summer.
species_data.habitat: Adults can be found from January to May, though nymphs (approximately 5mm long) can be seen from December; Active during the day, particularly when sunny.
species_data.distribution: Common below 1600m in the New South Wales alps; less common in Victoria but can be found in some subalpine areas. Often found along road verges and can co-occur with Kosciuscola tristis, Kosciuscola usitatus and Kosciuscola cuneatus.

groups_data.label: Frogs and Reptiles
groups_data.description: FROGS AND REPTILES (order Anura) are really scary :S

groups_data.label: Crickets and grasshoppers
groups_data.description: CRICKETS AND GRASSHOPPERS (order Orthoptera) can be recognized by their flat-folded wings (if present) and enlarged hindlegs. Usually found in grass, low shrubs, or on the ground.
